results.title: Vesalius, founder of modern anatomy
results.creator_credit: Thomas R. Forbes, Yale University School of Medicine and Susan Wheeler
results.brief_description: Documentary on Andreas Vesalius, born in 1514 in Brussels. Appointed Professor of Anatomy at Padua in 1536, he revolutionised anatomy with clear and succint lectures and dissections of cadavers. In 1543 his seven books on the structure of the human body was published - a comprehensive work which describes bones, muscles, blood vessels, nervous system, abdominal and thoracic viscera and head. The work corrected anatomical myths dating back to Roman times and emphasised the wholistic structure of the body. His use of detailed illustrations and emphasis on dissection and observation paved the way for modern anatomy and physiology.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Thomas R. Forbes, Yale University School of Medicine and Susan Wheeler

results.title: Very nice very nice
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Colin Low, Tom Daly and Arthur Lipsett
results.brief_description: Arthur Lipsett’s first film. It looks behind the business-as-usual face we put on life and shows anxieties we want to forget. It is made of dozens of pictures that seem familiar, with fragments of speech heard in passing and, between times, a voice saying, “Very nice, very nice.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Colin Low, Tom Daly and Arthur Lipsett

results.title: Very important person [Study extract]
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, Society for Education in Film and Television, Julian Wintle, Leslie Parkyn and Ken Annakin
results.brief_description: An extract from “Very Important Person”, directed by Ken Annakin. Features Farrow’s relations with other prisoners who suspect him of being a spy, his accidental discovery of the escape tunnel, and his encounter with the Camp Commandant on parade. Cast includes James Robertson Justice, Leslie Phillips, Stanley Baxter, Eric Sykes, Richard Wattis.

results.title: Very good friends
results.creator_credit: Martin Tahse, Richard Bennett, Learning Corporation of America and Martin Tahse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learning to be human”.
Based on the novel “Beat the Turtle Drum” by Constance Greene. Deals with a thirteen-year-old girl’s reactions to the death of her younger sister, to whom she was very close. Starring Melissa Sue Anderson, Katy Kurtzman.

results.title: Very dangerous
results.creator_credit: James Hamilton, ONF | NFB and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: This film deals with the extent, transmission, symptoms and treatment of gonorrhoea and syphilis. Animated diagrams illustrate the male anatomy and the course of infection. The value of blood tests and early proper treatment are emphasised. Through cooperation with health authorities and with knowledge these very dangerous venereal diseases can be wiped out. Revised version of the Royal Canadian Air Force Film, It’s Up to You (307799)

results.title: Vertical spindle moulding machine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Woodworking machinery series”
Short description of machine, moulding and rabbeting stiles, rails and bar of sash. Setting the cutters, use of face board. Franking, cutting tenons to length. Other uses, the Whitehall cutter block, French or slotted head.

results.title: Vertical
results.creator_credit: David Hall and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Both a simple catalogue of verticals and a series of visual paradoxes exploring illusions of straightness and squareness and the notion of frame. A stimulus film showing recurrence of geometrics in nature. No dialogue.

results.title: Versifier
results.brief_description:
Gina Czarnecki’s ‘Versifier’ places the viewer alone in a room with nine naked figures.
Varying in age, race and gender, ‘Versifier’s‘ pale figures are without identity or voice, like spectres of people with a hidden past that has occurred long before our arrival. Rearprojected onto a vast screen stretched like skin across the space, these human forms suggest early nineteenth-century museum exhibits: human specimens stripped of protective layers and preserved eternally in a captive vessel.

Currently heading the Electronic Imaging Department at the University of Dundee, Gina Czarnecki works at the intersection of film, video and computer-generated imagery. In describing ‘Versifier’ she explains, ‘I have always loved the cinematic experience and came to realise that I wanted this in an installation environment. There is something about being in the dark in a public space that focuses your eyes and attention onto small details, sounds, people in the space with you or your inner thoughts and solitude.’

Once enclosed within Czarnecki’s installation, the viewer focuses on the exposed
inhabitants. With its confronting interface, Versifier challenges notions of modesty,
candour, embarrassment, fascination. Experiences that we tend to take for granted are offered up for creepily clinical re-examination. Czarnecki has used digital technology to manipulate the figures into disquieting hybrid forms: skin tones are unusually monochromatic, limbs appear disproportionate and distended. The body itself - the medium through which we all experience the world - takes on disturbing new definitions inside the specimen room that is Versifier.

Czarnecki’s mutant characters gesture forward to contemporary anxieties about the looming new frontier of genetic modification, manipulation and experimentation. But they also point backward to personal memories of vulnerability or exposure, and to communal memories of the Holocaust and genocide in which bodies were lined up and exposed in ways that were an affront to all accepted definitions of humanity. In fact, Czarnecki’s disturbing yet beautiful parade calls into question everything - past, present and future - that makes us human in the most basic, naked way.

results.title: Versailles: the palace of the sun
results.brief_description: Presents the man-made beauties of the Palace of Versailles, built for the “Sun-King”, Louis XIV. Shows the famous Hall of Mirrors. Lingers on the many works of sculpture and shows the Trianons, the Queen’s Hamlet, and the great gardens designed by La Notre.
